intro: Streptanthus cordatus var. duranii, commonly known as the Sierra Nevada bladderpod, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky habitats and has a compact, low-growing habit. Its leaves are pinnately divided and covered in fine hairs, and it produces yellow or white flowers in early spring. This variety is distinguished by its geographic distribution and specific morphological traits adapted to its alpine environment.
